articles.headline: A Passion Play Endures as a Seasonal Miracle
articles.snippet: Mike Graham has for a quarter century been the guiding force behind “The Story of Jesus,” full of miracles and betrayals, exotic animals and a cast of hundreds.
articles.abstract: Mike Graham has for a quarter century been the guiding force behind “The Story of Jesus,” full of miracles and betrayals, exotic animals and a cast of hundreds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAUCHULA, Fla. — With less than two hours until showtime, a man sits amid the backstage chaos and studies his image in a propped-up mirror. The eyes are grayish blue, the goatee trim, the long dark hair flecked with gray. Not there yet. He scoops another dab of makeup to continue the annual transformation of Mike Graham, now 58, into Jesus Christ, forever 33.

articles.headline: A Camera That Honors Old Virtues
articles.snippet: The new Fujifilm X100 camera is made for people who actually know something about photography and don’t need scene modes.
articles.abstract: The new Fujifilm X100 camera is made for people who actually know something about photography and don’t need scene modes.

articles.headline: Labor Board Tells Boeing New Factory Breaks Law
articles.snippet: The National Labor Relations Board says in a complaint that the company chose South Carolina for its new 787 Dreamliner production line in retaliation against a union, which is illegal.
articles.abstract: The National Labor Relations Board says in a complaint that the company chose South Carolina for its new 787 Dreamliner production line in retaliation against a union, which is illegal.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what may be the strongest signal yet of the new pro-labor orientation of the National Labor Relations Board under President Obama, the agency filed a complaint Wednesday seeking to force Boeing to bring an airplane production line back to its unionized facilities in Washington State instead of moving the work to a nonunion plant in South Carolina.

articles.headline: Invitation to Israeli Leader Puts Obama on the Spot
articles.snippet: A Republican invitation for Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to address Congress kicked off a diplomatic race to reopen Israeli-Palestinian talks.
articles.abstract: A Republican invitation for Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to address Congress kicked off a diplomatic race to reopen Israeli-Palestinian talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Republican invitation for Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to address Congress next month is highlighting the tensions between President Obama and Mr. Netanyahu and has kicked off a bizarre diplomatic race over who will be the first to lay out a new proposal to reopen the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

articles.headline: Tracking File Found in iPhones
articles.snippet: Two programmers said their research showed that Apple iPhones and iPads began tracking and storing their locations in a hidden file a year ago.
articles.abstract: Two programmers said their research showed that Apple iPhones and iPads began tracking and storing their locations in a hidden file a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple faced questions on Wednesday about the security of its iPhone and iPad after a report that the devices regularly record their locations in a hidden file.

articles.headline: A Web Edge for Makers of Real Stuff
articles.snippet: Bringing a physical product to market can be risky, but inventors are getting around the hurdles — in part by using the Web to find backers and buyers.
articles.abstract: Bringing a physical product to market can be risky, but inventors are getting around the hurdles — in part by using the Web to find backers and buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Plenty of people want to build a popular Web site and become the next Mark Zuckerberg. But some technology entrepreneurs have a more old-fashioned goal: they want to make something you can hold in your hand.

articles.headline: In Online Games, a Path to Young Consumers
articles.snippet: Food marketers are pitching their products to children via Web sites that critics say blur the line between activities and advertising.
articles.abstract: Food marketers are pitching their products to children via Web sites that critics say blur the line between activities and advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: HESPERIA, Calif. — Deep into one of her favorite computer games, Lesly Lopez, 10, moves her mouse to click on a cartoon bee. She drags and drops it into an empty panel, creating her own comic strip.

articles.headline: Concern Grows Over Window Blind Safety
articles.snippet: Industry and safety advocates are sparring over whether enough is being done to prevent fatal accidents.
articles.abstract: Industry and safety advocates are sparring over whether enough is being done to prevent fatal accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: On an idyllic August day in 2009, Kathleen Leeson took her children to church, fed them leftover pizza and planned to take them to the park.

articles.headline: Inferior Arms Hobble Rebels in Libya War
articles.snippet: The armed uprising is not adequately armed and has many weapons with no utility in the war at hand.
articles.abstract: The armed uprising is not adequately armed and has many weapons with no utility in the war at hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — A PKT machine gun, a weapon designed to be mounted on a Soviet tank and fired electronically by a crew member inside, has no manual trigger, no sights and no shoulder stock. That does not prevent many Libyan rebels from carrying it as if it were an infantryman’s gun.

articles.headline: Quake and Fuel Expense Cut Into Carriers’ Revenue
articles.snippet: Analysts say that the airlines are still expected to make a profit this year because of an upturn in business travel.
articles.abstract: Analysts say that the airlines are still expected to make a profit this year because of an upturn in business travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first quarter is always weak one for airlines, as travel drops with the start of the new year. But this one was especially difficult, the airlines reported Thursday, as fuel prices spiked and Middle East unrest and the earthquake in Japan cut into demand for international flights.
